messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Graph Structure of an Inversive Pseudorandom Number Generator over Ring ‚Ñ§_ùëù^ùëí

Paper Abstract: Abstract Generating random and pseudorandom numbers with a deterministic system is a long-standing challenge in theoretical research and engineering applications. Several pseudorandom number generators based on the inversive congruential method have been designed as attractive alternatives to those based on the classical linear congruential method. This paper discloses the least period of sequences generated by iterating an inversive pseudorandom number generator over the ring ‚Ñ§esubscript‚Ñ§ùëí\mathbb{Z}_{e} by transforming it into a two-order linear congruential recurrence relation. Depending on whether the sequence is periodic or ultimately periodic, all states in the domain can be attributed to two types of objects: some cycles of different lengths and one unilateral connected digraph whose structure remains unchanged concerning parameter eùëíe. The graph structure of the generator over the ring ‚Ñ§esubscript‚Ñ§ùëí\mathbb{Z}_{e} is precisely disclosed with rigorous theoretical analysis and verified experimentally. The adopted analysis methodology can be extended to study the graph structure of other nonlinear maps.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Chaos-based random number generators-part I: analysis",
        "On the quality of random sequences produced with a combined random bit generator",
        "Cycle structures of a class of cascaded FSRs",
        "New results on modular inversion hidden number problem and inversive congruential generator",
        "Periodicity analysis of Logistic map over ring ‚Ñ§3nsubscript‚Ñ§superscript3ùëõ\\mathbb{Z}_{3^{n}}",
        "Cryptanalysis of an image block encryption algorithm based on chaotic maps",
        "On a method by D. H. Lehmer for the generation of pseudo random numbers",
        "Random number generators: good ones are hard to find",
        "Lehmer random number generator",
        "Random numbers generated by linear recurrence modulo two",
        "The art of computer programming, volume 2: seminumerical algorithms, 3rd ed.",
        "Generalized Lehmer-Tausworthe random number generators",
        "The kùëòk-distribution of generalized feedback shift register pseudorandom numbers",
        "Criteria for the assessment of random number generators",
        "Linear recurring sequences over rings and modules",
        "Compression mappings on primitive sequences over Z/(pe)ùëçsuperscriptùëùùëí{Z}/(p^{e})",
        "The properties of a class of linear FSRs and their applications to the construction of nonlinear FSRs",
        "A fully integrated chaotic system for the generation of truly random numbers",
        "Pseudorandom bits generated by chaotic maps",
        "Low-hardware complexity PRBGs based on a piecewise-linear chaotic map",
        "On combination of stochastic and deterministic processes",
        "The digital Tent map: performance analysis and optimized design as a low-complexity source of pseudorandom bits",
        "Dynamic analysis of digital chaotic maps via state-mapping networks",
        "Logistic map: A possible random-number generator",
        "The graph structure of the generalized discrete Arnold‚Äôs Cat map",
        "Period distribution of generalized discrete Arnold Cat map for n=peùëõsuperscriptùëùùëín=p^{e}",
        "On the security of public-key algorithms based on Chebyshev polynomials over the finite field Znsubscriptùëçùëõ{Z}_{n}",
        "Security analysis of the public key algorithm based on Chebyshev polynomials over the integer ring Znsubscriptùëçùëõ{Z}_{n}",
        "A class of maximum-period nonlinear congruential generators derived from the R√©nyi chaotic map",
        "Inferring sequences produced by pseudo-random number generators",
        "Pseudorandom bit generation using coupled congruential generators",
        "Modified dual-CLCG method and its VLSI architecture for pseudorandom bit generation",
        "Solving a class of modular polynomial equations and its relation to modular inversion hidden number problem and inversive congruential generator",
        "A non-linear congruential pseudo random number generator",
        "Inversive and linear congruential pseudorandom number generators in empirical tests",
        "On the statistical independence of nonlinear congruential pseudorandom numbers",
        "A new inversive congruential pseudorandom number generator with power of two modulus",
        "Average equidistribution and statistical independence properties of digital inversive pseudorandom numbers over parts of the period",
        "Inversive pseudorandom numbers over Galois rings",
        "On the Inversive Pseudorandom Number Generator",
        "On inversive maximal period polynomials over finite fields",
        "Exponential sums and the distribution of inversive congruential pseudorandom numbers with prime-power modulus",
        "Exponential sums and the distribution of inversive congruential pseudorandom numbers with power of two modulus",
        "A nonlinear congruential pseudorandom number generator with power of two modulus",
        "On the period length of congruential pseudorandom number sequences generated by inversions",
        "The period lengths of inversive pseudorandom vector generations",
        "The graph of the Logistic map is a tower",
        "The graph structure of Chebyshev polynomials over finite fields and applications",
        "The functional graph of linear maps over finite fields and applications",
        "Dynamics of polynomial maps over finite fields",
        "Introduction to finite fields and their applications, 2nd ed.",
        "Lectures on finite fields and Galois rings"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Graph Structure of an Inversive Pseudorandom Number Generator over Ring ‚Ñ§_ùëù^ùëí, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
